014package org.jdbi.v3.core.array;
015
016import java.lang.reflect.Type;
017import java.util.List;
018import java.util.Optional;
019import java.util.UUID;
020import java.util.concurrent.CopyOnWriteArrayList;
021import java.util.function.Function;
022
023import org.jdbi.v3.core.config.ConfigRegistry;
024import org.jdbi.v3.core.config.JdbiConfig;
025import org.jdbi.v3.core.enums.internal.EnumSqlArrayTypeFactory;
026import org.jdbi.v3.core.interceptor.JdbiInterceptionChainHolder;
027import org.jdbi.v3.core.internal.JdbiOptionals;
028import org.jdbi.v3.meta.Alpha;
029
030/**
031 * Configuration class for SQL array binding and mapping.
032 */
033public class SqlArrayTypes implements JdbiConfig<SqlArrayTypes> {
034
035    private final JdbiInterceptionChainHolder<SqlArrayType<?>, SqlArrayTypeFactory> inferenceInterceptors =
036        new JdbiInterceptionChainHolder<>(InferredSqlArrayTypeFactory::new);
037
038    private final List<SqlArrayTypeFactory> factories = new CopyOnWriteArrayList<>();
039    private SqlArrayArgumentStrategy argumentStrategy;
040
041    private ConfigRegistry registry;
042
043    public SqlArrayTypes() {
044        argumentStrategy = SqlArrayArgumentStrategy.SQL_ARRAY;
045
046        register(boolean.class, "boolean");
047        register(Boolean.class, "boolean");
048        register(short.class, "smallint");
049        register(Short.class, "smallint");
050        register(int.class, "integer");
051        register(Integer.class, "integer");
052        register(long.class, "bigint");
053        register(Long.class, "bigint");
054        register(float.class, "float4");
055        register(Float.class, "float4");
056        register(double.class, "float8");
057        register(Double.class, "float8");
058        register(String.class, "varchar");
059        register(UUID.class, "uuid");
060        register(new EnumSqlArrayTypeFactory());
061    }
062
063    private SqlArrayTypes(SqlArrayTypes that) {
064        factories.addAll(that.factories);
065        argumentStrategy = that.argumentStrategy;
066        inferenceInterceptors.copy(that.inferenceInterceptors);
067    }
068
069    /**
070     * Returns the strategy used to bind array-type arguments to SQL statements.
071     *
072     * @return the strategy used to bind array-type arguments to SQL statements
073     */
074    public SqlArrayArgumentStrategy getArgumentStrategy() {
075        return argumentStrategy;
076    }
077
078    /**
079     * Sets the strategy used when binding array-type arguments to SQL statements.
080     *
081     * @param argumentStrategy the argument strategy to set
082     * @return this
083     */
084    public SqlArrayTypes setArgumentStrategy(SqlArrayArgumentStrategy argumentStrategy) {
085        this.argumentStrategy = argumentStrategy;
086        return this;
087    }
088
089    /**
090     * Register an array element type that is supported by the JDBC vendor.
091     *
092     * @param elementType the array element type
093     * @param sqlTypeName the vendor-specific SQL type name for the array type.  This value will be passed to
094     *                    {@link java.sql.Connection#createArrayOf(String, Object[])} to create SQL arrays.
095     * @return this
096     */
097    public SqlArrayTypes register(Class<?> elementType, String sqlTypeName) {
098        return register(SqlArrayTypeFactory.of(elementType, sqlTypeName, Function.identity()));
099    }
100
101    /**
102     * Register a {@link SqlArrayType} which will have its parameterized type inspected to determine which element type
103     * it supports. {@link SqlArrayType SQL array types} are used to convert array-like arguments into SQL arrays.
104     * <p>
105     * The parameter must be concretely parameterized; we use the type argument {@code T} to determine if it applies to
106     * a given element type.
107     *
108     * @param arrayType the {@link SqlArrayType}
109     * @return this
110     * @throws UnsupportedOperationException if the argument is not a concretely parameterized type
111     */
112    public SqlArrayTypes register(SqlArrayType<?> arrayType) {
113        SqlArrayTypeFactory factory = inferenceInterceptors.process(arrayType);
114
115        return register(factory);
116    }
117
118    /**
119     * Register a {@link SqlArrayTypeFactory}. A factory is provided element types and, if it supports it, provides an
120     * {@link SqlArrayType} for it.
121     *
122     * @param factory the factory
123     * @return this
124     */
125    public SqlArrayTypes register(SqlArrayTypeFactory factory) {
126        factories.add(0, factory);
127        return this;
128    }
129
130    /**
131     * Obtain an {@link SqlArrayType} for the given array element type in the given context
132     *
133     * @param elementType the array element type.
134     * @return an {@link SqlArrayType} for the given element type.
135     */
136    public Optional<SqlArrayType<?>> findFor(Type elementType) {
137        return factories.stream()
138                .flatMap(factory -> JdbiOptionals.stream(factory.build(elementType, registry)))
139                .findFirst();
140    }
141
142    @Override
143    public void setRegistry(ConfigRegistry registry) {
144        this.registry = registry;
145    }
146
147    /**
148     * Returns the {@link JdbiInterceptionChainHolder} for the SqlArrayType inference. This chain allows registration of custom interceptors to change the standard
149     * type inference for the {@link SqlArrayTypes#register(SqlArrayType)} method.
150     */
151    @Alpha
152    public JdbiInterceptionChainHolder<SqlArrayType<?>, SqlArrayTypeFactory> getInferenceInterceptors() {
153        return inferenceInterceptors;
154    }
155
156    @Override
157    public SqlArrayTypes createCopy() {
158        return new SqlArrayTypes(this);
159    }
160}
